interpretation: The greater the perceived responsibility for the cause of the situation attributed to other people/objects, the greater the anger.
The greater the perceived imminent threat in the situation, the greater the anger.
The greater the perceived fairness of the situation, the less the anger.
The greater the perceived control over the situation, the less the anger.
The greater the perceived relevance of the situation to one's goals, the greater the anger.
The greater the perceived ability to cope and adapt to the situation, the less the anger.
The greater the consistency of the situation with one's goals, the less the anger.
The greater the perceived value of the situation to one's goals and desires, the less the anger.
The greater the perceived pleasantness of the situation, the less the anger.
The greater the consistency of the situation with external and social norms, the less the anger.
The greater the perception that something irretrievable has been lost, the greater the anger.
The greater the need to exert effort to deal with the situation, the greater the anger.
The greater the perceived harm, the greater the anger.
The greater the perceived difficulty, the greater the anger.
The greater the perception that an obstacle hampers the attainment of a desired goal, the greater the anger.
The greater the ability to predict what is going to occur in the future, the less the anger.
The greater the perceived severity of the consequences of the situation to one's well-being, the greater the anger.
The greater the consistency of the situation with one's ideals, the greater the anger.
The greater the perception that a threat or harm has been removed from the situation, the less the anger.
The greater the perception that effort could make the situation better, the less the anger.
The greater the perception that the situation could be modified, the less the anger.
The greater the perception of others as dispositionally evil, the greater the anger.

The greater the consistency of the situation with one's ideals, the greater the love.
The greater the perceived ability to cope and adapt to the situation, the greater the love.
The greater the perceived relevance of the situation to one's goals, the greater the love.
The greater the perception that effort could make the situation better, the greater the love.
The greater the perceived novelty in the situation, the greater the love.
The greater the perception of how unique the situation was, the greater the love.
The greater the expectation that the situation will get better, the greater the love.
The greater the perceived need to take time/effort to attend to the situation further, the greater the love.
The greater the consistency of the situation with external and social norms, the greater the love.
The greater the concern for others' well-being in the situation, the greater the love.
The greater the perceived temporal distance to a remembered past situation, the less the love.
